history.content:
This seems like a DP problem, because it is similar to the knapsack problem: Each item has a "cost" of including in the knapsack, a "benefit" associated with including it, and a constraint that it can't exceed a certain "cost". The problem is that the constraint is not an integer, so there are an infinite number of possibilities in the solution space.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8953331/limitations-of-dynamic-programming-algorithm 

I wonder if the solution isn't just the greedy approach of putting in one ball at a time, starting with the smallest balls, until you get to the theoretical maximum you could include. Then shake the box until they arrange themselves properly.

This seems like a DP problem, because it is similar to the knapsack problem: Each item has a "cost" of including in the knapsack, a "benefit" associated with including it, and a constraint that it can't exceed a certain "cost". The problem is that the constraint is not an integer, so there are an infinite number of possibilities in the solution space.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8953331/limitations-of-dynamic-programming-algorithm

children.subject: these seems to me to be a version of the knapsack problem. Except here the "value" is the same as the "weight" and instead of "weight" you have volume (and a corresponding volume limit).

history.content:
I feel this is a DP problem, but I am not sure how to solve it.

[redefine the problem as integer problem, according to feedback below].

There are n rigid balls with radius 1 .. n, and there is a cubic box with edge length of 2*n. The task is to use those balls to fill the box as full as possible. Each ball can be used only once.

The task is to dump rigid balls to a cubic box, whose total volume is L^3.  (L is the edge length of the cubic). 

R = [r1, r2, .., rn] stores the radius of each ball, and there are more than enough balls to make the box full. 

(a) Determine the minimum empty space/volume of the cubic, after filling all possible balls.

(b) Which balls are used?

(c) What if each ball can be used m times ?

*Implicit spatial constraint: all rigid balls are stacked together, and they will not go beyond the box boundary as shown below.
history.subject: Fill a box with balls -Dynamic Programming

I feel this is a DP problem, but I am not sure how to solve it.

[redefine the problem as integer problem, according to feedback below].

There are n rigid balls with radius 1 .. n, and there is a cubic box with edge length of 2*n. The task is to use those balls to fill the box as full as possible. Each ball can be used only once.

The task is to dump rigid balls to a cubic box, whose total volume is L^3.  (L is the edge length of the cubic). 

R = [r1, r2, .., rn] stores the radius of each ball, and there are more than enough balls to make the box full. 

(a) Determine the minimum empty space/volume of the cubic, after filling all possible balls.

(b) Which balls are used?

(c) What if each ball can be used m times ?

*Focus on question (a)

history.content:
I feel this is a DP problem, but I am not sure how to solve it.

The task is to dump rigid balls to a cubic box, whose total volume is L^3.  (L is the edge length of the cubic). 

R = [r1, r2, .., rn] stores the radius of each ball. Each ball can be used only once, and there are more than enough balls to make the box full. 

(a) Determine the minimum empty space/volume of the cubic, after filling all possible balls.

(b) Which balls are used?

(c) Is it possible to determine the center coordinates of each ball (assume box center is (0,0,0))?

*Focus on question (a)
history.subject: Fill a box with balls -Dynamic Programming

The task is to use balls to fill in a cubic, and its total volume is L^3.  (L is the edge length of the cubic).

R = [r1, r2, .., rn] stores the radius of each ball. Each ball can be used only once, and there are more than enough balls to make the box full.

(a) Determine the minimum empty space/volume of the cubic, after filling all possible balls.

(b) Which balls are used?

(c) Is it possible to determine the center coordinates of each ball (assume box center is (0,0,0))?

*Focus on question (a)
